metadata.topic_title: API Call Volume and Success Rate

active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the relative importance of API call volume vs. success rate for threat detection. Provide examples from real-world scenarios (e.g., NCSC.gov.uk DoS guidance) and propose how to combine them with other metrics like latency for better accuracy.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Threat Intelligence Platforms under Operational Metrics (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Threat Intelligence And Hunting > Threat Intelligence Platforms > 013_Metrics and Effectiveness Measurement > Operational Metrics > API Call Volume and Success Rate). Generate high-quality, spaced-repetition optimized flashcards using university pedagogy: Bloom's Taxonomy (cover all 6 objectives provided), active learning (inspire critical thinking via scenarios), 4-layer scaffolding (build from foundation to integration), and web-grounded context (NIST SP 800-228 API Protection Guidelines, OWASP API Security Top 10, MITRE ATT&CK API tactics like T1106, sources: sei.cmu.edu, ncsc.gov.uk). Incorporate: Definitions (API volume=total requests, success=% 2xx), anomaly detection (spikes=DoS/brute-force), best practices (baselines, alerting), connections (prereqs: APIs/HTTP; related: SIEM/latency; apps: SOC dashboards), interactive elements (sample data: e.g., 1000 calls, 850 success=85%). Voter consensus: Complete standards, pedagogy progression, knowledge integration. Output a JSON array of 30 flashcards, each strictly following this schema: {"front": "...", "back": "...", "explanation": "...", "bloom_level": "Remember|Understand|Apply|Analyze|Evaluate|Create", "scaffolding_layer": "Layer 1|2|3|4", "tags": ["array"], "type": "MCQ|Definition|Cloze|Calculation|Scenario"}. Use distractor protocol for MCQs: 3 plausible wrongs (misconceptions, partial truths, extremes). Ensure variety, measurability, and active recall. No duplicates; cover all layers/objectives evenly.
